positive.review:
HumanitZ is the video game equivalent of being given a to-do list while your house is on fire. A very, very detailed to-do list.
The goal is simple: don't die. The execution is you, from a god's-eye view, desperately trying to remember if you left a can of beans in that one house while six zombies politely shuffle towards you to eat your face. Itâ€™s a top-down, co-op survival sim where you'll spend 80% of your time joyfully looting every last piece of scrap and 20% of your time screaming as a horde you totally didn't see ruins your day.
The charm is in the beautiful chaos. One minute you're a master carpenter building your dream apocalypse fortress, the next you're a panicked rat running from a zombie bear because you forgot to eat your can of beans. Bringing a friend just means you have a witness to your glorious, stupid demise.

A fantastically stressful playdate. Highly recommended for anyone who thinks "What's the worst that could happen?" is a fun starting point for an evening.

My wife, our friend and myself all bought this game. I've only put in 14.5 hours but I've really been enjoying this game. It does have it's issues but that's to be expected of an early access game. First I'd like to talk about the pros.

Pros:
- I enjoy how the zombies feel like actual zombies. Going for the head makes a difference, you have to deal with them crawling should their legs "break" and the are also different types of zombies which keeps things fresh.

- I've just had an in-game day of driving around and looting with a car. Myself and the other party members all got in our cars and headed out. I with my ACP, my friend with her souped up truck and my wife who was evel knievel going down the road. Seeing her fly over a ramp and landing on another car is absolutely hilarious and then my friend and myself ramming zombies and NPC characters left and right is amazing. 

- The survival aspect in my opinion is on point. There's always that need to improve your gear/sufficiency and the need to go out and loot. Keeping your hunger and hydration up in the beginning can be a little hard but I enjoy it because it makes everything feel that much better when you have some more self sufficiency and supplies at your base. 

Cons: (I'm doing this with intent that it hopefully reaches the devs and notifies new players)
- I love that you can place items and rotate them but it is a PAIN to pick up the item you want quite often. The ability to cursor over an item or something would make organizing so much better. I've found that I really enjoy having my car parts on warehouse shelves but had to put them in a storage container because it's just so hard/impossible to pick the specific item I want from the shelf.

- When building various structures the "build" or "add materials" function is a pain to find at times and can often lead to you being stuck in the thing you are building. I feel that this could be avoided and something better implemented. 

- Making it easier to upgrade/customize weapons with attachments. It doesn't seem very intuitive and we find ourselves wondering which weapons can take which attachments. This also goes in-hand with vehicle modifications.

Overall though, this is a wonderful game and I hope it gets more support. It has it's issues but that's to be expected. If you enjoy post apocalyptic zombie survival games then I bet you'll enjoy this one.

At this point in time, I highly recommend grabbing this game. Imo it's worth every penny of the current Â£15.49 asking price, even prior to 1.0.

good coop game but it still need some important features like, flip car or push it if its stuck or to have the ability to choose which items you want to pick up individually especially if you place a bunch of items on a table but all in all a very chill game

For an Early Access game that's been around for over 2 or 3 years now, pretty good, obviously needs more touch ups and optimizations, especially when driving. Driving around is the only laggy part of the game which is understandable cuz you render more of the map but that shouldn't be an issue nontheless cuz exploration is part of the game. To summarize my experience....

- World and the whole map looks and feels great but it lacks objective, I know its an open-world survivor game but I find myself getting bored when I fully set up a base and its defenses but then I got nothing to do afterwards.

- Weapons and modifications, great BUT i should have the option to use the scope and remove the attachments, having them permanently in the weapon kind of negates its whole purpose. They are "attachments" not permanent upgrades.

- Vehicles, Vehicle Armor, and mods, PERFECT, chef's kiss <3

- Base building is so good BUT there should be more choices for traps and there should be an alternative for the power generator cuz FUEL IS THE MOST SCARCITY in the game imo, crafting them is more of a hassle than just finding them in your supply runs, I recommend adding the option to craft a windmill that generates electricity to power up anything electricity related.

- Weather and other Weather events are very well crafted, storm feels scary and the night is perfectly dark that compliments the danger of zombies or raiders.

- Camera feels janky and cursor is stupidly wonky. I love it when the camera zooms in when you go indoors but when you leave and it immediately zooms out, hate it, cant see my character cuz the roof of the building I was in is blocking the view. Cursor is wonky, its fine but it still needs fixing, best way to describe it is when I want to aim left or right in combat stance its forcing itself to go back to the middle of the screen which throws off majority of my aim, the same goes for my friends.

Lastly I would recommend the devs to rework all the friendly NPCs, weird how raiders and zombies are the only ones roaming the map coming across you base but never friendly NPCs that fight back, I'd recommend letting NPCs roam and maybe (hopefully) give us an option to take them in and giving them tasks like guarding our base from attacks, monitoring the power generator, car maintenance, supply runs, or even forming a team of 4 (you and 3 NPCs) to come with you on your supply runs backing you up, perfect for solo worlds or with friends to cover more ground.

LOVE THE GAME, BUY IT ON SALE THOUGH, FUN GAME BUT STILL LAGGY AND SOMETIMES BUGGY WHICH IS FINE AND UNDERSTANDABLE KNOWING ONLY 6 PEOPLE ARE WORKING ON THIS GAME. KEEP IT UP DEVS, GAME IS AWESOME AND WITH MORE FIXES AND OTHER CONTENT UPDATES, IT'LL BE BETTER.

HumanitZ is the video game equivalent of being given a to-do list while your house is on fire. A very, very detailed to-do list.
The goal is simple: don't die. The execution is you, from a god's-eye view, desperately trying to remember if you left a can of beans in that one house while six zombies politely shuffle towards you to eat your face. Itâ€™s a top-down, co-op survival sim where you'll spend 80% of your time joyfully looting every last piece of scrap and 20% of your time screaming as a horde you totally didn't see ruins your day.
The charm is in the beautiful chaos. One minute you're a master carpenter building your dream apocalypse fortress, the next you're a panicked rat running from a zombie bear because you forgot to eat your can of beans. Bringing a friend just means you have a witness to your glorious, stupid demise.

This game is a mixture of Project Zomboid and State of Decay. The building is impressive and free range within reason. I am impressed with the server settings as customization is expansive and clever. It feels like the truest survival/crafting game on the market, in my opinion and my preferred taste. The map is wide in length, even though with future updates, I can image a much deeper area of exploration will happen. What the game lacks is the ability to recruit survivors so they can help attend to your base's needs and provide added protection. Would be helpful having survivors tagging along with you on adventures.

TL;DR 
First Impression: Overall good. Recommended.
20hrs in
I like 7 Days to Die and State of Decay, this game scratches an itch that other comparable titles do not, while drawing on familiar mechanics that don't feel like cheesy copypasta crap. 

The open world is very large. I currently have about a third of the map discovered and so far am enjoying a healthy variety of POIs that keep me guessing...and assessing my surroundings. 

Some random things that stood out to me...
The vehicle mechanics are like State of Decay but better. Fuel management is reasonably challenging, forcing me to do mini expeditions in search of fuel. Gas stations are very fruitful if you find them early, otherwise you may find yourself scrounging for other cars to siphon small amounts of fuel from. For every vehicle, there are basic components that need to be maintained or replaced (tires, starter, fuel pump, etc) and virtually no vehicles are found on the map with a complete set of parts. For this reason, getting multiple vehicles running at the same time with a full tank of gas is both challenging and rewarding. All parts can be directly transferred from donor cars meaning if you find an obvious upgrade in the field you can move everything over from an existing car immediately. This is particularly meaningful when you start dabbling in crafting the tiered modular armor upgrades on your vehicles, which in it of itself comes with nicely done visual changes to the wide variety of cars for that Mad Max look. All the cars are aptly renamed with cute play-on-words that can be likened to an early GTA and Saints Row-esque approach to navigating around intellectual property lawsuits. It makes me chuckle. 
Repair kits are pretty available to find and craft, making vehicle management less about managing damage and more about keeping them fed and finding the appropriate parts to get additional cars running. The vehicle physics is about what you would expect for this game, which is not focused on suspension/ground clearance/mass at all. The game does make a point of using uneven terrain surfaces between "civilized" parts of the map, and when driving, it lets you know its there by either sending the vehicle airborne unexpectedly or mantling it on some poorly-defined rock surface. On a brighter side, the vehicles do hit pretty good top speeds which is extremely helpful for long distance looting runs, with a very noticeable stability loss at high speeds that will have you really feathering the A and D keys. Vehicles do actually fish tail with overcompensation complete with squealing tires and treadmarks, which was a completely welcome surprise for a game in this genre. 
The game is very forgiving with ramming zombies - you can run down large groups before you start having a significant impact on vehicle condition. For this reason, I've often forgone shooting in the more urban areas in favor of ramming. Repair kits are easier to replace than ammo. 

The weapons are reasonably diverse. So far ammo has been pretty scarce so I typically start shooting only when dealing with Hostile NPCs and special zombies. Repair kits can be made to keep them from breaking, modular attachments can be added. There doesn't seem to be anything particularly noteworthy about the gun mechanics other than its all there and it more or less works. The camera angles don't really play nice with the shooting mechanics, especially when shooting at targets that are above, such as zombies on a rooftop or a hostile NPC in a watchtower. You can kill armored zombies with guns by shooting their helmet a few times, but there's really no way to fine tune the aim accordingly, and I just end up dumping a mag until it does the thing. Long range shooting is wanky - put a scope on a rifle, the map zooms out so you can "see further" but your target is now smaller making it harder to get a precise shot. Given the quasi top-down perspective, not really sure how to improve this other than doing a first/third person perspective change when using scoped guns. 

Melee is closer to state of decay style, with large and small item slots that allow for weapons and tools interchangeably. The inventory management aspect makes sense but because of the "hand" slot, fast switching to say, an axe in slot 1 removes the axe from slot 1 and puts it in "hand" freeing up slot 1. When you're looting in a hurry, it's very easy to auto-populate an empty slot making it impossible to quickly free up your hand, which can lead to time-killing interruptions or potentially dropping the equipped item and forgetting to pick it up. The melee combat comes with decent, albeit limited combat animations that is neither overly exciting nor feeling like the same animation on constant loop. Mining ore is clumsy and awkward, and the tree chopping animations is clunky at best (pun intended). Everything melee works, but with little grace.

The crafting system is OK. Inventory management will be a bottleneck early on, as I quickly amassed more items than storage. Weight management is also relatively unforgiving until you start to learn strategies for your playstyle. The crafting and building options are limited and certain items do require a decent amount of grind to craft. Ingredients and options are laid out pretty clearly and they do make sense, however the game currently does not offer much guidance in the beginning. You kind of need to just figure it out. 

There is a pretty wide variety of clothing items that can come with small boosts. Very similar to 7 days with a wider selection.

Looting structures is fun. There's the token stuff you find in every house, and typically a little something extra stashed away that you don't see all the time. There's something very satisfying about walking up to the front door, finding it's locked, and immediately going to the nearest window, smashing it in, jumping through, and unlocking the door from the other side. Lockpicking is basically fallout, but on the hard/very hard side. Lockpicks are not particularly common and break very easily. The loot distribution seems to have been done with forethought. Ammo containers contain ammo, dressers contain clothes, the trunk of a police cruiser contains a body vest, a shotgun, etc. This does make it easier to plan where to go and what to search. Furniture inside buildings can be dismantled for crafting components, which you should exploit early game. There is a limited selection of things that can be dismantled inside, and virtually nothing outside. I'm hopeful the options expand down the line, because this (and hard terrain) is one of the main things that will make the open world feel more sandboxy as the game seems to want to achieve evidenced by the commendable flexibility of slapping base walls anywhere, including filling out doorways and gaps if you take over a building and need some "traffic control". Random hostile AI and zombie herds come to you, wherever you plant roots.  

Map can be tricky. Many structures do not actually appear on the map. Some might find this frustrating, but for me there's a level of immersion that I enjoy from a map that gets me in the right general direction but doesn't give me an almost spoiler-esque preview of what's out there. Player marks their own POIs, using a limited selection of icons that can stamped. It's very easy to accidentally un-stamp a location you mark. 

There is currently not much in the way of NPCs. You will occasionally run into a single NPC who will trade from a very limited pool, and if you're lucky they might offer a short fetch-quest. There is also scattered pockets of hostile NPCs that will shoot at you on-sight. The AI is poor, they follow 2005-era pathfinding and in groups this occasionally turns into a hillarious spicy congo-line.

The camera angle and mechanics do work, and there are different settings to adjust. There are also 3rd party mods that integrate a true 3rd person camera angle (doesn't help much with shooting). 

Worth

My partner and I discovered HZ a couple of weeks ago after a brief stint with PZ. While PZ certainly offers deeper mechanics, I found the lack of graphical fidelity made it harder for me to stay immersed. HZ, on the other hand, captures many of the core mechanics that make PZ great but pairs them with visuals that truly bring the experience to life.

Iâ€™m really glad we picked it up during Early Access, especially with Version 1.0 set to launch before the end of the year. The HZ Discord is also well worth joining the devs are active, responsive, and genuinely engaged with the community.

Iâ€™m genuinely excited for the 1.0 release and canâ€™t wait to see where development goes from there.

Iâ€™ve been playing HumanitZ for over 90 in-game days on a private server, and I never saw a single car spawn â€” not even a broken-down vehicle. I had loot respawn set to abundant, and I explored almost the entire map, but vehicles simply didnâ€™t appear. After creating a fresh server as a test, cars spawned normally, which shows the issue isnâ€™t luck â€” itâ€™s a bug in older saves or existing worlds.

Additionally, about 25% of the map is water, which makes large portions of the world unusable. I really wish the map was bigger, as it feels cramped and limits exploration.

I love the concept and the world, but the combination of broken vehicle spawns and the limited map made my experience frustrating. Please fix vehicle spawn behavior in ongoing saves and consider expanding the map.

UPDATE:
My original server was bugged due to a demo save name issue. Starting a fresh world fixed the missing vehicle problem. With the new updates, the cars now work as they should, and the addition of new backpacks makes the game much more enjoyable. The changes to the map in the update also make the world feel better overall, and the game feels far more enjoyable now. This game has great potential as the devs keep improving it.

ðŸ•’ Hours Played: Technically 0 on Steam, but letâ€™s just sayâ€¦ Iâ€™ve done extensive QA testing (40+ hrs) elsewhere.
ðŸ’¾ Early Access Review

"HumanitZ is shaping up nicely, but still feels like itâ€™s missing a few crucial bolts in the survival machine."

First off, major respect to the devs for being actively present in the Early Access space. In 2025, thatâ€™s sadly become a selling point on its own. The bar is so low, itâ€™s undergroundâ€”but these devs are at least digging in the right direction.

Mechanically, the game has a solid foundation. Controls are clean and responsive, and traversal feels natural. That said, the aiming system feels like it was designed by someone who spent one too many hours playing isometric RPGs with a loose mouse. It works, but thereâ€™s definitely a "getting-to-know-you" phase before it feels intuitive.

Inventory variety? Minimal. If loot was a buffet, HumanitZ is currently serving rice and water. The game desperately needs more weapons, outfits, gear, and general post-apocalyptic flavor. You can only find the same 9mm pistol so many times before it starts to feel like you're looting a very boring arms dealer.

And then thereâ€™s melee combatâ€¦ oh boy. Ever tried hitting a zombie and watching it justâ€¦ not care? No flinch, no stagger, just pure undead indifference. Feels less like youâ€™re fighting zombies and more like youâ€™re politely tapping mannequins who are late for a meeting. A solid hit reaction systemâ€”especially for meleeâ€”would go a long way toward making combat feel impactful and not like you're swinging a pool noodle at an existential threat.

Still, despite the jank and content gaps, I found myself coming back (again, in totally legitimate, non-illegal ways). Thereâ€™s something here worth watching. With more loot variety, better hit feedback, and continued dev support (which they are providing), HumanitZ could easily become a standout in the survival genre.

Verdict: A solid zombie survival title in early stages. Needs more meat on the bones (both in zombies and features), but worth keeping an eye onâ€”especially if you like your games slightly janky and full of potential.

I've enjoyed my time thus far, although I'd say it still needs some time - for the cost though it's been worth it.

Looking at what's being planned still, I feel isn't what the game needs. The largest issue I see currently is the interior of buildings. Nearly all of them look identical, with the same generic layout and furniture. That really should be what's worked on next, because how the game is now is already quite solid, but the mundane buildings really hurts a game that's about going into buildings and looting.

There should be different flooring, different furniture and themes inside them. I understand the timeline seems to be in the distant future of an apocalypse, yet that doesn't tend to translate well into games, even State of Decay suffers from boring interiors. Pull it back slightly, and give a little more life into the designs of interiors. Carpets, furniture that isn't fully dilapidated. Part of what makes me want to replay games as this is the potential for a base in a different theme. Mall base, arcade base, those are things that go through my head amongst other things when I consider replaying a game. Even the hours I have in it's repetitive.

Generally, this game isn't hindered with anything major, performance is fine, gunplay works, combat is fine, multiplayer doesn't lag, camera is... okay--be really great if we could put the screen upwards a bit more. 

[h3][b]Humanitz has the opposite problems of most games today - it's all small things.[/b][/h3]

-Needs quick stack, badly.

-ctrl+right click breaks when looting from a chest, requiring you to manually press both buttons for each item.

-Interiors need... they need life guys. Should be top prio in my opinion.

-Camera limits need to be tweaked, allowing us to look up and out farther.

-Moveable furniture needs to be apart of the interior rework. Being able to pick up a fridge or storage would be wonderful.

-When inside a building, the camera needs to pull a Sims half wall view fully, including for buildings attached to buildings. Again, interior stuff. It can get really janky when going inside buildings.

-Stack size for items needs set to 999--full clean water bottles needs to be stackable especially--This is a problem older survival games had that has largely been fixed by modern games of the genre.

-NPCs turn into brick walls when you're inside a car. Meaning if one runs up to the car to shoot while you're stationary, you cannot move your car in that direction sometimes. 

This looks like a lot of issues, but it isn't - it's all minor things that are mainly parameters and design. The interiors could be fixed by giving randoms assets to fix things around the map. And the game would be incredibly solid. It's already been a great experience, I've been losing time while playing from my enjoyment.

My biggest hope is the game doesn't devolve too hard into questing--aka the 7DTD route, bleh--and it also doesn't focus too hard on PvP. As right now, it feels a lot more like Day-Z than Zomboid. Actually it reminds me most of Miscreated which shut down years ago, and I really hope it does go a more simplified Zomboid route as those past Zombie survival games died for good reason.

Pull back the apocalypse timeline a little. Give buildings more life due to it. More things laying around, food containers in stores, even if just for aesthetic with nothing in them. Breath some life into the architecture. 

It's a yes from me right now, hopefully they keep up the work and this really becomes a hidden gem. It's on the right track, stay the course.

My wife, our friend and myself all bought this game. I've only put in 14.5 hours but I've really been enjoying this game. It does have it's issues but that's to be expected of an early access game. First I'd like to talk about the pros.

Pros:
- I enjoy how the zombies feel like actual zombies. Going for the head makes a difference, you have to deal with them crawling should their legs "break" and the are also different types of zombies which keeps things fresh.

- I've just had an in-game day of driving around and looting with a car. Myself and the other party members all got in our cars and headed out. I with my ACP, my friend with her souped up truck and my wife who was evel knievel going down the road. Seeing her fly over a ramp and landing on another car is absolutely hilarious and then my friend and myself ramming zombies and NPC characters left and right is amazing. 

- The survival aspect in my opinion is on point. There's always that need to improve your gear/sufficiency and the need to go out and loot. Keeping your hunger and hydration up in the beginning can be a little hard but I enjoy it because it makes everything feel that much better when you have some more self sufficiency and supplies at your base. 

Cons: (I'm doing this with intent that it hopefully reaches the devs and notifies new players)
- I love that you can place items and rotate them but it is a PAIN to pick up the item you want quite often. The ability to cursor over an item or something would make organizing so much better. I've found that I really enjoy having my car parts on warehouse shelves but had to put them in a storage container because it's just so hard/impossible to pick the specific item I want from the shelf.

- When building various structures the "build" or "add materials" function is a pain to find at times and can often lead to you being stuck in the thing you are building. I feel that this could be avoided and something better implemented. 

- Making it easier to upgrade/customize weapons with attachments. It doesn't seem very intuitive and we find ourselves wondering which weapons can take which attachments. This also goes in-hand with vehicle modifications.

Overall though, this is a wonderful game and I hope it gets more support. It has it's issues but that's to be expected. If you enjoy post apocalyptic zombie survival games then I bet you'll enjoy this one.

This game really took me by surprise. I needed my DayZ-like fix on my Legion Go and this game ended up being something special. It runs great on my handheld device. Although the graphics arenâ€™t anything amazing, the game still looks great. Those thunderstorms are honestly pretty scary.

The survival gameplay is fun without being overly punishing. Managing food, water, heat and sickness is way less annoying than in a lot of other zombie survival games.

The music is great too. It can get a bit repetitive after a while, but it really helps with the atmosphere.

The zombies, or Zeeks, are surprisingly well done with lots of different variants. Some are fast, some are slow, some are huge and some walk around in body armor.

The base building is a big highlight for me. Turning an abandoned house into your own safe place feels incredibly satisfying.

In single player you can adjust the server settings however you like. Things like respawn timers, how fast hunger and thirst drain or how long the nights are. It really lets you shape the experience to your taste.

If I have to name a downside, itâ€™s the name HumanitZ. Iâ€™m really not a fan. It feels a bit cheap

For an Early Access game that's been around for over 2 or 3 years now, pretty good, obviously needs more touch ups and optimizations, especially when driving. Driving around is the only laggy part of the game which is understandable cuz you render more of the map but that shouldn't be an issue nontheless cuz exploration is part of the game. To summarize my experience....

- World and the whole map looks and feels great but it lacks objective, I know its an open-world survivor game but I find myself getting bored when I fully set up a base and its defenses but then I got nothing to do afterwards.

- Weapons and modifications, great BUT i should have the option to use the scope and remove the attachments, having them permanently in the weapon kind of negates its whole purpose. They are "attachments" not permanent upgrades.

- Vehicles, Vehicle Armor, and mods, PERFECT, chef's kiss <3

- Base building is so good BUT there should be more choices for traps and there should be an alternative for the power generator cuz FUEL IS THE MOST SCARCITY in the game imo, crafting them is more of a hassle than just finding them in your supply runs, I recommend adding the option to craft a windmill that generates electricity to power up anything electricity related.

- Weather and other Weather events are very well crafted, storm feels scary and the night is perfectly dark that compliments the danger of zombies or raiders.

- Camera feels janky and cursor is stupidly wonky. I love it when the camera zooms in when you go indoors but when you leave and it immediately zooms out, hate it, cant see my character cuz the roof of the building I was in is blocking the view. Cursor is wonky, its fine but it still needs fixing, best way to describe it is when I want to aim left or right in combat stance its forcing itself to go back to the middle of the screen which throws off majority of my aim, the same goes for my friends.

Lastly I would recommend the devs to rework all the friendly NPCs, weird how raiders and zombies are the only ones roaming the map coming across you base but never friendly NPCs that fight back, I'd recommend letting NPCs roam and maybe (hopefully) give us an option to take them in and giving them tasks like guarding our base from attacks, monitoring the power generator, car maintenance, supply runs, or even forming a team of 4 (you and 3 NPCs) to come with you on your supply runs backing you up, perfect for solo worlds or with friends to cover more ground.

I tried to get over it, I couldn't.  When you hold a melee weapon, the crosshair is still there and you need to aim with your crosshair, this feels very weird. I grabbed a log, the character puts it on his shoulder and I wanted to drop it...I couldn't. Many things I tried to do....I just couldn't. 

I don't like giving thumbs down to an early access game, and maybe if you can get used to the cam angle and the weird quick slot issues, it might be for you...but it isn't for me.

Further findings:

you cant exit the game, you will have to open task manager for that. 
trading items often steals your items without completing transaction. 
putting logs in vehicle or container deletes at least 10 minutes of your life as it doesnt add to the inventory.

The game definitely needs polishing, things such as dropping a lighter on the ground and it instantly gets eaten up (aka no item highlighting) and I have to move my mouse all around the ground in hopes of it picking up wherever it dropped. And this is only at the tutorial stage where you had to burn a pile of wood. Fast forward to actual gameplay, the servers are numerous, though quite empty at times. Issues: 
- Gameplay needs polishing...a lot.
- Camera needs to be reworked.
- Items needs to have an icon when dropped (or you could hold a keybind to highlight items on the ground)
- Sound can get messy, sometimes its loud and sometimes its soft.
- The overall UX and UI needs to be refined, the main menu looks horrendous and the font is too small for a 34" widescreen monitor

The good:
- Models are great, they look great, move great and react as they should
- Weather is good, would be even better if lightning randomly strikes the ground in thunderstorms and maybe randomly hits an enemy or player if they're not under cover.
horrible camera angle, very limited building options.  pointless story.
Game was good but since latest patches got laggy not optimised i can run project zomboid and 7 days to die, but this one lags like crazy. Friends had similar experience.

You want a pain in the butt game mechanics. You want a game where you lose the cursor for the map and crafting every 30 mins or less and takes a complete exit and reload of game to get it back. THIS BUG HAS BEEN THERE SINCE LAUNCH AND THEY REFUSE TO FIX IT OR CANT EITHER WAY A STRONG PASS!!

A worse version of Project Zomboid in every way imaginable, even graphically somehow.  At least in PZ I can zoom the camera out pretty far.  This game?  Forget it.  You can see about 20 feet. 
This is like playing Project Zomboid with the Fallout: Brotherhood of Steel engine and camera.  Fallout: BoS came out for the PlayStation 2 over 20 years ago and is hailed as the worst Fallout game of all time by a wide margin.  Even more than Fallout 76 at launch.

i use unbuntu 24
its pretty crap. If you doing an animation you can't interupt it. thats how I died.

My game soft locked in the tutorial when traversing between menus causing the character to be in an endless loop of animations. I decided it's too large of a red flag to be worth my time and / or money so I requested a refund.

I tried to like this game, but couldn't. The devs tried to come up with a "different" system of holding things and how the quick slots work. I tried to get used to it, I couldn't. The cam prevents you to see around as it can't get any lower then a certain height. This is not ideal. When you get indoors, this problem becomes even worse. You can't see where you're walking into...You get into a house, there are zombies in there, you hear them but you can't see what your character should be seeing...because you know, he is standing there. I tried to get over it, I couldn't.  When you hold a melee weapon, the crosshair is still there and you need to aim with your crosshair, this feels very weird. The zombie is standing infront of me, but my character turns his back to him with this weird scheme of, I think they call it stance maybe...anyways another thing I couldn't get over. I grabbed a log, the character puts it on his shoulder and I wanted to drop it...I couldn't. Many things I tried to do....I just couldn't. 

I don't like giving thumbs down to an early access game, and maybe if you can get used to the cam angle and the weird quick slot issues, it might be for you...but it isn't for me.
It crashed on steam deck consistently. I tried every fix i could find, from changing the version of proton, to adjusting the in game settings. I donâ€™t recommend.

I will change my review to POSITIVE if:
1. My HORSE not suddenly disappear in multiple protection stable even the way blocked by barbwire, I only found HORSE SADLE lies on the ground.
2. If ANTIDOTE can completely cures INFECTION. AT the moment only reloading last save point can make Infection gone, so what is the reason to search scarce ingredients if it waste of time.

So it's an interesting idea but could have used more time in the oven before going early access. The UI is clunky, the combat is clunky, and while I don't expect hand holding not much is explained...like how to sleep. Basic QoL stuff like being able to quickly swap items from inventory to storage isn't a thing so you have to drag everything. Basically you have to do a LOT of menu navigation and while I get working cars are scarce you would think starting as a mechanic she would have an easier time getting car parts to get a car working. But in two hours the only car I could interact with is the broken one in the starter area.

It's an intersting premise but is more tedius to play than sandbox survival should be.
Great game. Terrible camera settings.
Sometimes I think I like these kind of games, but ultimately I get so bored.
Too slow, can't be bothered to see if gets better
this game sucks ass
Just not for me

- controls are clumsy
- camera is just bad in every setting
- no hit feedback at all. you hit a zombie with a knife and it doesnt stagger or flinch at all. it just hits you back.

just a bad version of project zomboid in every point
The game has potential, but definitely isn't there yet. The new-player experience is rough and I love zombie survival games.

It's not a bad game, but its not my kind of game. The world feels, plain and empty without a lack of cohesiveness. Maybe the game is for you, some people enjoy it, but I think it needs to cook a lot more.

The UI is eh, camera is wonky going in and out of buildings, some areas are completely bare and empty, like no cracks in concrete or litter on ground. Combat needs fleshing out, sometimes you get hit and it doesn't make any sense. You cannot interact with a lot of stuff, like some buildings have floors blocked off and thats part of the model, and a lot of cars you can only loot the trunk as its a static object.

This is an early access review, so maybe they will turn it around. If nothing else, its good to at least try when its on sale.

I wanted to recommend, but I don't feel that there is enough content in the game to justify the price. I feel I did just about everything with the game time I have accumalated. My coop buddy and I enjoyed what was on offer, but this is probably closer to the $10 price point at it's current stage of development. There is no story, and the development of the game seems pretty slow. The gameplay was fun, but I would have liked to have had an army base or something populated by like 50 humans with rewards to match the efforts. I'm not trying to dog on the game..... but this just needs to cook a little longer. I guess by the general rule of thumb, I did get my money's worth ($1/hr played), $20, for about 25hrs of content. Loved the style of gameplay, just needs more.

constant bugs, hardlocked my entire PC, combat is terrible, map is inaccurate, been out for 2 years and the basic bugs such as cursor disappearance hasnt been fixed? not worth your money. Go buy another project zomboid wannabe.

Further findings:

you cant exit the game, you will have to open task manager for that. 
trading items often steals your items without completing transaction. 
putting logs in vehicle or container deletes at least 10 minutes of your life as it doesnt add to the inventory.

The game definitely needs polishing, things such as dropping a lighter on the ground and it instantly gets eaten up (aka no item highlighting) and I have to move my mouse all around the ground in hopes of it picking up wherever it dropped. And this is only at the tutorial stage where you had to burn a pile of wood. Fast forward to actual gameplay, the servers are numerous, though quite empty at times. I do own state of decay and this does seem similar but the horrid camera work just puts me off this game.

Bought the game, then refunded. Might buy back if issues are fixed and things seem better.
